posts.name: Angad
posts.cooked:
The VH-109 won’t connect to our rio2. We have wires going into the 12v input (so it gets power), and an ethernet going from the “rio” port on the radio to the rio. The radio blinks with the status light which (checking the docs) means it can’t connect to 10.27.91.4 (our team is 2791 so i assume that’s what that means when it says 10.xx.yy.4)

Reflashed the radio with updated firmware. Success

Changed the wifi name, password, and team number (successful, turning on the 2.4g wifi network gave us the one with the correct SSID, using the web interface again gave us the correct team number)

Connect the rio to the laptop and run arp -a . Turns out we’re getting the rio’s link-local IP address (both arp and DS reported an IP which had the prefix which the rio docs said was link-local)  instead of it’s DCHP.

Attempt to force it to use the DHCP using the web interface. Computer would no longer connect to rio over ethernet. Used usb to recover and change it back. It’s IP ended up going to 0.0.0.0

Attempt to force it to use 10.27.91.4 and 10.27.91.2 using the static option. In both cases, the computer would not connect to the rio.

Any help would be appreciated. Thanks

posts.name: Tauseef Afraz
posts.cooked: Have you taken a look at this?

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Set up as DHCP the radio gives the RIO its IP address.

Double-check you have the team-number set on the RIO via the web interface. You may have forgotten to set it after imaging (like my and many others teams the last few days have). If the RIO does not have the correct team-number set, it will not be given the correct IP address by the radio.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked:
10.TE. AM .4 is the IP address of the gateway when connected to the field network or the VH-109/113 running the AP practice firmware.

If you are setting static IP addresses, use 10.TE. AM .2 with a subnet mask of 255.255.255.0 for the roboRIO and 10.TE. AM .5 with a subnet mask of 255.0.0.0 for the DS computer

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.name: Angad
posts.cooked: Should I be configuring the radio as an AP rather than a robot radio? All our laptops have wifi 6e support - will it be necessary to buy another radio?

posts.name: Graham Howard
posts.cooked: Yes, unfortunately. FCC does not permit using a 6ghz AP in this use case (I believe it’s battery operated), so you have to use a second radio or 2.45ghz.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
As @grahamsh mentioned for connection between the robot and your DS you will need 2 radios (you can use 2.4ghz but there are a dozen or so threads on CD about the difficulties with that (power throttling reducing distance/performance, band congestion, etc…))

Once you have a 2ed radio (one on the robot one stationary plugged into the wall) - you can potentially use your laptops wifi6E to connect to the AP on the bench instead of needing to hardware - but you cannot connect directly to the robot radio with your laptop as I understand it currently.
